key_points: Policymakers are debating who should receive the next round of stimulus checks as part of the American Rescue Plan.
Before receiving stimulus checks, spending patterns in low-income and high-income families were similar.
After the stimulus checks were distributed on January 4, 2021, spending by low-income families increased significantly.
High-income households spent significantly less of their stimulus checks compared to low-income families.
The use of real-time economic data from credit card and payroll companies is advocated to guide policy decisions.
The $600 stimulus payments saw immediate significant spending by low- and middle-income households.
Analysis predicts that providing $1,400 to higher-income households would result in less immediate economic activity.
The recession has impacted low- and high-income people differently, with high-income individuals saving more.
Approaches using real-time data are argued to be more effective in guiding policy than relying on historical data.
Localized economic data can reveal diverse experiences across America, aiding targeted support and relief efforts.
